subtasks: Wait until temperatures are warm and there's no risk of frost before planting caladium tubers.
Determine the depth at which to plant the tubers based on local precipitation and temperature conditions.
If unsure of the orientation, plant the tubers shallow and on their side to ensure correct growth.
Pot caladium tubers in an all-purpose potting mix, adding slow-release fertilizer and compost, maintaining planting depth similar to original.

tasks.task: Caring for Caladium Bicolor during Growing Season
subtasks: Keep soil consistently moist but well-draining. Water early in the day and adjust frequency based on light and temperature.
Apply regular liquid fertilizer (e.g., half-strength seaweed-based) every three weeks during active growth.
Protect plants from slugs, snails, and aphids using baits or other pest controls.
Position plants in full to partial shade, ensuring morning sun for optimal growth.
Companion plant with impatiens for aesthetics and moisture management.
Divide or repot as needed while flowering and seed heads develop.
Stop fertilizing and reduce watering when temperatures cool to 55-50°F and prior to frost.
Lift tubers from the garden or stop watering if potted. Trim foliage and roots.
Store tubers in a cool, dry place (above 60°F) using perlite or peat moss, and apply a fungicide as needed.
Re-pot or divide stored tubers after several weeks of rest and resume care in spring.
Monitor stored tubers for signs of mold or rot and address issues promptly.
